body: This is why some attributes actually have an Order property, like some of those in Asp.Net.

rename.to: Author Tests assume ICustomAttributeProvider.GetCustomAttributes return order is defined

body: I have not examined all the other AllowMultiple attributes in NUnit to see if any of them have similar problems.  That is why I did not make this specific to the Author attribute

The Author property seemed to be well behaved in terms of the stack order. But that order is enforced by the test properties. 

Never tried comparing it to customattributes.

I only found this when I ported these changes to my CF build, and the Author test failed.

I had never specifically thought about the issue before, perhaps intuitively just not doing it :(

I did review the PR, but did not notice the potential problem.

In my case, TestMethodMultipleAuthors returned them in the order Rob Prouse, NUnit, Charlie Poole.

TestFixtureMultipleAuthors returned them in the order specified in the test.

That is, unfortunately, the nature of undefined :)

@JustinRChou The order of the property values is the same as the order that the attributes were found. So they will be different when using different runtimes. We sometimes see differences between Mono and .NET and always between .NET and .NETCF. Because we no longer build CF, I guess it's now easier for a mistake to slip through. In fact, IIRC, I think I suggested you use Is.EqualTo in the first place! ðŸ˜Š
Changing to Is.EquivalentTo fixes the tests
If there is a desire to allow a specific ordering of authors, then an optional property Order could be added to the AuthorAttribute.

@JustinRChou I assigned this to you.

@oznetmaster No reason to need ordering that I can see.

The quoted test is correct, even if it could be better written.

Datapoint and Datapoints attributes are not obsoltete. They are completely unrelated to DatapointSource, in spite of the name similarlity.

I'd say just stick to fixing the error in AuthorTests to resolve this issue.
